title: PCT 45: Wisahketchahk visits his little brother, the duck
author: Coming-Day

sentences.original: wîsahkêcâhk owîkimâkanah tah ê-wîkicik nôhtêhkatêw.
sentences.english: Wisahketchahk was starving where he dwelt with his wife.

sentences.original: sipwêhtêw; mâcîw.
sentences.english: He went away; he went hunting.

sentences.original: kîtahtawê êh-pimohtêt, wâpahtam mîkiwâhp, êh-takohtêt.
sentences.english: Presently, as he walked along, he saw a tent and went up to it.

sentences.original: êkotah skwâhtêmihk ômis itwêw : ham, ham! - itwêwak, nika-kiskêyimik, êh-itêyihtahk.
sentences.english: There in the doorway he went, “Hem, hem!” - thinking, “If I make this noise in his hearing, he will know me.”

sentences.original: pîhcâyihk ôhi k-âpiyit ayîsiyiniwah êkosi ômisiy itwêyiwah : hâw, tawâw, tawâw; pîhtokê! itwêyiwah.
sentences.text: pîhcâyihk ôhi kâ-apiyit ayîsiyiniwa êkosi ômisi itwêyiwa itwêyiwa
sentences.english: The person who sat within spoke thus: “Well, come in, come in; there is plenty of room!” he said.

sentences.original: êkosi ômisih itwêw wîsahkêcâhk : yahâ, nisîm, itah êcik ôma wiyîkiyin!
sentences.english: Thereupon Wisahketchahk said, “Oho, Little Brother, so this is where you live!”

sentences.original: ahag, itwêyiwa.
sentences.english: “Why, yes,” said the other.

sentences.original: pîhtokêw; nahapiw.
sentences.english: He went in and sat down.

sentences.original: nîso pikôw wâpamêw, nâpêwah êkwah owîkimâkaniyiwah.
sentences.text: nîso piko wâpamêw nâpêwa êkwa owîkimâkaniyiwa
sentences.english: He saw only two persons, the man and the man's wife.

sentences.original: ôtah iskwâhtêmihk asiniyah apiyiwah.
sentences.english: There by the door lay a big stone.

sentences.original: êkwah wiyah nama kêkway wâpahtam tê-mîcisot.
sentences.text: êkwa wiya nama kêkway wâpahtam tê-mîcisot
sentences.english: He saw nothing to make a meal of.

sentences.original: êkosi ômisi itwêyiwah : hâ, nôtokêsiw, akos askihk; nipiy sîkinah, itwêyiwah.
sentences.english: Then the other said, “Ho, Old Woman, hang up the kettle; pour in some water.”

sentences.original: êkosi awa nôtokêsiw akotêw askihkwa.
sentences.english: So the old woman hung up the kettle.

sentences.original: êkosi awa nâpêw pasikôw, asiniyah ôhi êh-kîhcêkosît.
sentences.text: êkosi awa nâpêw pasikôw asiniya ôhi ê-kîhcêkosît
sentences.english: Then the man rose to his feet and climbed up on the stone.

sentences.original: omisî itwêw, asinîhk êh-apit : kwêk kwêk kwêk! itwêw, tâpiskôc sîsîp.
sentences.text: ômisi itwêw asinîhk ê-apit itwêw tâpiskôc sîsîp
sentences.english: Sitting on the stone, he said, “Quack, quack,” like a duck.

sentences.original: hâ, nôtokêsiw, kitaskihk omis îsih iyipên!
sentences.english: “Hey, Old Woman, tip your kettle this way!”

sentences.original: êkwah, kwêk kwêk kwêk, k-êtwêt, êkosi omisi tôtam : ôma oskât ohpinam, êh-mîsît askihkohk.
sentences.text: êkwa kâ-itwêt êkosi ômisi tôtam ôma oskât ohpinam ê-mîsît askihkohk
sentences.english: Then, while crying “Quack, quack, quack,” he did this:  he lifted his leg and muted into the kettle.

sentences.original: mahtâminah askihkohk pahkisiniyiwah.
sentences.english: Grains of Indian corn fell into the kettle.

sentences.original: êkosi êkonih kîsiswêw ana iskwêw.
sentences.english: Then the woman boiled them.

sentences.original: êkosi êkonih, wîsahkêcâhk êh-mîcisot, asamâw tê-mîcisot wîsahkêcâhk.
sentences.text: êkosi êkoni wîsahkêcâhk ê-mîcisot asamâw tê-mîcisot wîsahkêcâhk
sentences.english: Then Wisahketchahk was given these to eat for his meal.

sentences.original: mistahi akâwâtamawêw oma kâ-tôtamiyit.
sentences.english: Greatly he envied the other this thing which he did.

sentences.original: ê-kîh-mîcisot, kîwêw.
sentences.english: When he had eaten he went home.

sentences.original: omis îtêw : nisîm, kisiwâk ôtah niwîkin.
sentences.english: Thus he spoke: “Little Brother, near by here I live.

sentences.original: pê-kiwokê, itêw.
sentences.english: Come visit us,” he told the other.

sentences.original: êkwah wiya kîwêw.
sentences.english: Then he went home.

sentences.original: êkwah cîk êy-ihtât wîkihk awa wîsahkêcâhk, asiniyah otinêw; kîwêhtahêw; pîhtokahêw.
sentences.text: êkwa cîki ê-ihtât wîkihk awa wîsahkêcâhk asiniya otinêw kîwêhtahêw pîhtokahêw
sentences.english: Then, when Wisahketchahk was near home, he took a big stone; he brought it home; he brought it into the lodge.

sentences.original: ôh ês ôwîkimâkanah ômisi itik : mohco-kisêyiniw, tânisi wâh-tôtaman, asiniy awah kâ-pîhtokahat ?
sentences.english: His wife said to him, “Crazy old fool, what are you going to do, that you're at bringing this big stone into the tent?”

sentences.original: êkosi wîsahkêcâhk ômisih itwêw wîsahkêcâhk : êkâya nânitaw itwêyak nôtokêsiw, itwêw wîsahkêcâhk :
sentences.text: êkosi wîsahkêcâhk ômisi itwêw wîsahkêcâhk itwêw wîsahkêcâhk
sentences.english: Thereupon to her said Wisahketchahk:  “Do not say anything, Old Woman,” said Wisahketchahk;

sentences.original: nisîm wîh-pê-kiwokêw; êkâya nântaw itwêhkan.
sentences.english: “My little brother is coming to visit us; when he comes, do you be still!”

sentences.original: êkosi pê-kiwokêyiwah osîmah; pîhtokêyiwah.
sentences.english: And so his brother cam a-visiting; into the tent he came.

sentences.original: hâ, tawâw, nisîm.
sentences.english: “Ho, come in, Brother!”

sentences.original: êh-apiyit êkosi omis îtwêw wîsahkêcâhk : nôtokêsiw, akos kitaskihk.
sentences.english: When the other had been seated, thus spoke Wisahketchahk: “Old Woman, hang up your kettle.”

sentences.original: nâh, tânisi wâh-tôtahk ? twêw notokêsiw.
sentences.english: “Yah, what does he think he is going to do?” said the old woman.

sentences.original: êkâya nântaw itwê, nôtokêsiw.
sentences.english: “Do not talk, Old Woman.

sentences.original: akos kiyâm kitaskihk.
sentences.english: Just hang up your kettle.”

sentences.original: êkosi awa nôtokêsiw akotêw, nipiy ê-sîkinahk.
sentences.text: êkosi awa nôtokêsiw akotêw nipiy ê-sîkinahk
sentences.english: So the old woman hung it up and poured in some water.

sentences.original: êkwah awa wîsahkêcâhk ati-âh-âhtapiw, asiniyah ôhi ê-kîhcêkosît, êkotah êh-apit kwêhk, kwêhk, kwêhk! êkotah êh-apit.
sentences.text: êkwa awa wîsahkêcâhk ati-âh-âhtapiw asiniya ôhi ê-kîhcêkosît êkota ê-apit êkota ê-apit
sentences.english: Then Wisahketchahk moved along, changing his seat, getting up on the stone, and saying, “Quawk, quawk, quawk,” as he sat there.

sentences.original: notokêsiw, pêy-iyipên kitaskihk.
sentences.english: “Old Woman, tilt your kettle this way!”

sentences.original: êkwah ohpwâmêyiw wîsahkêcâhk, êh-mîsît : nama kêkway mahtâminah, pisisik mêyih.
sentences.text: êkwa ohpipwâmêyiw wîsahkêcâhk ê-mîsît nama kêkway mahtâmina pisisik mêyi
sentences.english: Then Wisahketchahk lifted his ham and muted:  by no means corn, but only dung.
sentences.footnote: LB on {ohpwâmêyiw}:  Probably the full form is {ohpipwâmêyiw}

sentences.original: êkosi nôtokêsiw ômis îtwêw : yipâcihêw otaskihkwah atimo-kisêyiniw.
sentences.english: The old woman said: “He is befouling his kettle, the dirty dog of an old man!”

sentences.original: êkwah awa kâ-kiwokêt pakwâtam, êh-wîhcêkaniyik mêyih êh-pasot.
sentences.text: êkwa awa kâ-kiyokêt pakwâtam ê-wîhcêkaniyik mêyi ê-pasot
sentences.english: And the visitor was disgusted, as he smelled the stinking excrement.

sentences.original: êkosi êyokôw.
sentences.english: That is all of this.
